Authors:
Qing Wen Zhao, Xiang-Hua Wang, Fei Xiao Shi, Rui Zhang,
Pei-Gui Liu
Title:
Molecular phylogeny and geographic structure of a basal
Suillus lineage associated with Larix in China
Abstract:
Suillus cavipes and species closely related with it formed
a basal lineage in the phylogeny of Suillus. These species are
exclusively associated with larches and distributed in
circumboreal-alpine regions. To explore Suillus species diversity in
Chinese larch forests and test if high continental endemism is present
in this group, we amplified ITS, LSU and tef1 sequences from 18
specimens collected from northeastern and subalpine southwestern China.
Phylogenetic analyses on the ITS-LSU- tef1 concatenated dataset revealed
three highly supported lineages that were recognized as three known
species, S. asiaticus, S. cavipes and S. paluster. In the ITS genealogy
generated from all available sequences of the basal lineage, three
subclades of S. cavipes and two subclades of S. paluster were resolved
by maximum likelihood analysis. These subclades might be putative
species or infraspecific taxa. Morphological variations were found among
these subclades, but formal description of the potential new species was
pending due to limited sampling. Samples from China cover all the
subclades in S. cavipes and S. paluster and S. asiaticus. All the
subclades, except one in S. cavipes, include samples from more than one
continent. This low continental endemism is unexpected in Suillus.
Molecular dating is needed to speculate the mechanism that shaped such
distribution.
